#Text=Norman Leslie ( soldier )
#Text=Norman Leslie ( died 29 August 1554 ) , was a 16th-century Scottish nobleman .
#Text=The leader of the party who assassinated Cardinal Beaton , he was forced to flee Scotland , serving the monarchs of England and France .
#Text=He died serving the latter in 1554 .
#Text=Family and early life

#Text=Norman was the eldest son of George Leslie , 4th Earl of Rothes , by Margaret , only daughter of William Crichton , 3rd Lord Crichton , denominated , 1 April 1517 , his ' sponsa affidata . ' . [ 1 ]
#Text=No marriage ceremony is recorded to have taken place , and the marriage was in 1520 declared null and void .
#Text=Norman seems to have been regarded as illegitimate . [ 2 ]
#Text=The notices in the ' Lord Treasurer 's Accounts ' in 1537 and 1539 of dresses furnished to him indicate that he at this time held some office at court .
#Text=On 7 December 1541 the office of sheriff of Fife , then made hereditary in the Rothes family , was bestowed on him for life , his father personally resigning it . [ 2 ]
#Text=He is described by Buchanan as a young man of such accomplishments that he had not his equal in all Scotland . [ 3 ]

#Text=He fought at Solway Moss in 1542 and was taken prisoner , but received his liberty as the result of the bond signed by the captive Scottish nobles to promote the interests of Henry VIII in Scotland .

#Text=To this is perhaps partly traceable his zeal against Cardinal Beaton , but it was at least quickened by an act passed , 12 December 1543 , at the instance of the cardinal , restoring to Sir James Colville the lands of Castle Wemyss , which on the forfeiture of Colville had been bestowed by James V on the Rothes family . [ 2 ]
#Text=Murder of Cardinal Beaton
#Text=On 17 April 1544

#Text=Henry VIII received information that the Master of Rothes and others were willing to undertake the slaughter of the cardinal as he passed through Fife , on condition that they had the assurance of Henry 's protection afterwards . [ 4 ]

#Text=Obtaining no satisfactory answer , they did not take advantage of the supposed opportunity , and subsequently , with his father , Norman appears to have given a pledge of personal service to the cardinal .
#Text=He actively supported Charteris , the nominee of Beaton , against Lord Ruthven , in their contest for the provostship of Perth . [ 5 ]

#Text=He also fought against the English at the battle of Ancrum Moor , 12 February 1545 , when his opportune arrival with three hundred spearmen from Fife , and with the news that the Scotts of Buccleuch were following on his heels , decided the Scots to risk the battle .
#Text=Negotiations for the murder of the cardinal were , with or without the sanction of Leslie , resumed with Henry on 30 May 1545 , and were continued till at least 20 October following . [ 6 ]
#Text=How much longer a blank in Henry 's Scottish correspondence renders it impossible to state . [ 2 ]
#Text=The execution of Wishart at the instance of the cardinal , 1 March 1546 , was apparently rather an opportune pretext for the cardinal 's assassination than the direct cause of it .
#Text=The statement of contemporary writers that Norman Leslie had not long before the murder a violent personal quarrel with Beaton seems probable .
#Text=Norman Leslie was the leader of the conspirators .

#Text=The castle of St. Andrews , where Beaton lived , was seized by men under his command , but he took no personal part in the act of assassination on 29 May 1546 , and John Leslie of Parkhill , his uncle , struck the fatal blow , after the cardinal had requested that Norman , whom he called his friend , should come to him .
#Text=A dagger erroneously reputed to have been used by Norman is preserved in Leslie House , Fife . [ 2 ]
#Text=After the murder
#Text=After the murder Norman and his associates took refuge in the cardinal 's stronghold .
#Text=They were besieged in St Andrew 's Castle by the governor of Scotland , Regent Arran .

#Text=On 11 March 1547 Norman and his colleagues , Henry Balnaves , James Kirkcaldy of Grange , and Alexander Whitelaw of Newgrange witnessed a pledge made by Patrick Gray , 4th Lord Gray to Edward VI . [ 7 ]
#Text=The lairds in the castle , sometimes called the Castilians , were summoned to answer for the murder , and , failing to do so , were on 30 July 1547 denounced as rebels .

#Text=On the same day the castle was surrendered to the French , and a condition having been made that the lives of all within it should be spared , its principal defenders were carried captives to France . [ 2 ]
#Text=Norman probably made his escape from France at the same time as Sir William Kirkcaldy of Grange , but there is no direct information on the point .
#Text=After his release , he , according to John Spottiswood , returned to Scotland , but on search being made for him he escaped by sea to Denmark .
#Text=Thence he crossed over to England , where for some time he was in the enjoyment of a pension from Edward VI . [ 2 ]
#Text=The accession of Queen Mary in 1553 compelled him to leave England , and he went to France , where he entered into the service of Henry II .
#Text=He was mortally wounded in an action before the stronghold of Renti , near Cambrai , on 14 August 1554 .
#Text=At the head of thirty Scots he heroically charged sixty horsemen armed with culverins , unhorsing five of them with his spear before it broke .
#Text=He made his way back to the constable of France , his horse dropping down dead at the constable 's feet . [ 2 ]
#Text=He was brought into the king 's tent , and died of his wounds on 29 August , fifteen days afterwards . [ 8 ]

#Text=His bravery and the manner of his death so impressed the French king that he used his influence with the queen-regent and the estates to obtain for the other confederates against Beaton the reversion of their lands . [ 2 ]
#Text=Leslie was married to Isobel Lindsay , daughter of John Lindsay , 5th Lord Lindsay , but left had no children with her .
#Text=He did however have two natural sons , named Robert and John . [ 9 ]
